rename.from: Please provide a way to opt out of JUnit Vintage engine deprecation
rename.to: Provide a way to opt out of JUnit Vintage engine deprecation

body:
Hi @TWiStErRob,

> So I would like to kindly ask for a way to silence this deprecation

I think that's a great idea, and in fact... we had already discussed this topic, but I forgot to raise an issue.

So, thanks for creating this ticket! ðŸ‘ 

> * [ ] An opt-out property.
> * [ ] Automatic detection of Robolectric/Android would be ideal.

This is in no way specific to Android. So, I don't think we should introduce any automatic opt out for Android.

For example, we ran into the same issue in the Spring Framework. We have officially deprecated our support for JUnit 4 in Spring; however, we still maintain the support we have. For the Spring Framework build we chose to fail the build for all JUnit discovery issues; however, that broke the build when we upgraded to JUnit 6, and I had to introduce the following _workaround_.

https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-framework/blob/30db2e4fb5e993ba6ada58d2d55ca4e82297e615/spring-test/spring-test.gradle#L113-L115

Of course, I don't actually consider that a viable workaround since it changes the severity for the entire `spring-test` module.

So, instead of an opt-out property, I think we should introduce a general purpose mechanism that allows projects to either suppress or alter the severity level for specific features.

This could be something analogous to how logging frameworks allow developers to configure the log level for specific log categories.

Thus, I envision some way to configure something along the lines of the following that would change the severity for the JUnit Vintage engine.

```properties
org.junit.vintage.engine.deprecation = none
```

For example, the "none" value _could_ be a new enum constant in [`DiscoveryIssue.Severity`](https://docs.junit.org/current/api/org.junit.platform.engine/org/junit/platform/engine/DiscoveryIssue.Severity.html) which would mean that the given _discovery issue category_ is disabled.

Of course, it's also imaginable that one could override the severity of a given _discovery issue category_ -- for example, by changing the default severity for the Vintage engine (which is hard coded in `VintageDiscoverer`) from `INFO` to `ERROR`.

```properties
org.junit.vintage.engine.deprecation = error
```

I think the prefixes for the categories should align with the package names for the features in question, and the last part ("deprecation" in the above examples) should succinctly describe the feature, analogous to the names we come up with configuration parameters.

Thoughts?

I also think we should introduce a reusable mechanism for this. Engines should be able to set an optional category for their discovery issues (such as `deprecation` in your example) and we should allow changing the severity as you suggested.

Moreover, I think we should use configuration parameters for this so we'd need some kind of prefix (similar to Spring using `logging.level.` for loggers), for example:

```properties
discovery.issue.severity.org.junit.vintage.deprecation = info
```

Setting `discovery.issue.severity.org.junit.vintage` would affect all discovery issues reported by the Vintage engine.

I'm not sure we need `none`. If `info` isn't logged by default (needs to be verified), it would be sufficient to reduce the severity to `info`, wouldn't it?
On second thought, I think we should use the engine ID (`junit-vintage`) instead of the package name (`org.junit.vintage`) since it's shorter and easier to determine.

issue.title: JUnit 6 warns about junit-vintage issue during test discovery

repository.name: pom
repository.description: Jenkins Parent POM for libraries and core components

issue.body:
### Jenkins and plugins versions report

<details>
  <summary>Environment</summary>

  <!-- Paste your environment details below -->
  ```text
Git plugin using parent pom 5.27
  ```

</details>


### What Operating System are you using (both controller, and any agents involved in the problem)?

Red Hat Linux

### Reproduction steps

1. Compile and test the git plugin and you'll see multiple warning messages of the form:
    ````
    (1) [INFO] The JUnit Vintage engine is deprecated and should only be used temporarily while migrating tests to JUnit Jupiter or another testing framework with native JUnit Platform support.
    Oct 07, 2025 6:11:47 PM org.junit.platform.launcher.core.DiscoveryIssueNotifier logIssues
    INFO: TestEngine with ID 'junit-vintage' encountered a non-critical issue during test discovery:
    ```


### Expected Results

I would prefer to not have the warning message when running tests.

### Actual Results

Warning message is displayed

### Anything else?

@strangelookingnerd do you have any insights to suggest how we should handle that new warning?

More information is available at:

* https://github.com/junit-team/junit-framework/issues/5030

### Are you interested in contributing a fix?

_No response_

body:
I also thought about using a prefix like Spring Boot does for logging, so you get a ðŸ‘ for that.

#### Entire Vintage Engine

```properties
discovery.issue.severity.junit-vintage = warning
```

#### Deprecation category for Vintage Engine
```properties
discovery.issue.severity.junit-vintage.deprecation = warning
```

I think those work nicely.

> I'm not sure we need `none`. If `info` isn't logged by default (needs to be verified), it would be sufficient to reduce the severity to `info`, wouldn't it?

I think we have been approaching this from the wrong angle.

Instead of reducing or changing the severity, developers will probably just need to specify the severity which should result in failure.

In other words, I think you're right (we don't need `none`), and we don't need to change or reduce the severity.

----

Let's look at Spring Framework as a concrete example.

For the entire Spring Framework build we set the global _critical_ severity to `INFO` so that all discovery issues will fail the build.

```properties
junit.platform.discovery.issue.severity.critical = INFO
```

For the `spring-test` module we currently have to override the global _critical_ severity and change it to `WARNING` so that only `WARNING` and `ERROR` discovery issues will fail the build.

```properties
junit.platform.discovery.issue.severity.critical = WARNING
```

So, for the use case in Spring, I'd like to replace the above with something like the following. Perhaps having `critical` in the property name would make it clearer?

```properties
discovery.issue.severity.junit-vintage = WARNING
```

That would still cause the build to fail for `spring-test` for all discovery issues, except those reported by the Vintage engine, and the build would only fail for Vintage discovery issues that have a severity of `WARNING` or `ERROR`.

Actually, I guess we have two use cases here.

1. The use case raised in this issue and https://github.com/jenkinsci/pom/issues/745 is about **suppressing logging** output for certain categories of discovery issues.
2. The use case in `spring-test` is about **not failing** the build for certain categories of discovery issues.

For `spring-test`, I am not so worried about the logging output for the Vintage engine, but I don't want `INFO` severity discovery issues to fail the build.

The original intention of this PR is to disable a certain type of discovery issue. This can be achieved by reducing the severity (and thereby the log level) or setting the severity to `none`.

I still think both uses cases can be addressed by adding a "category" to discovery issues and providing a way to set their severity (to `none` in this case).

I like the conclusion :) My builds did not fail, it's just the fact that messages are automatically printed to console [stderr]; I couldn't find me configuring logging where I saw this. I would happily fix any deprecation that has a possible replacement, and for that I would go all in and configure critical=INFO even (I always use warnings as errors where possible). But this only works if the messages are all actionable in some way. Having the option to opt out of something unfixable is something I'm strongly behind.

Re Android/Spring: I don't know what your third-party-mention-in-library-code policy is, but these are two very large user bases, so it would be nice if there was some out-of-the-box support for for them. Rather than having to configure this in most/all of the Android projects (because Robolectric is pretty wide-spread too) is there a way to detect these envs and set that above mentioned severity by default to none? I know Robolectric is detectable by [looking for `org.robolectric.RobolectricTestRunner`](https://cs.android.com/androidx/android-test/+/main:ext/junit/java/androidx/test/ext/junit/runners/AndroidJUnit4.java;l=59-70?q=getRunnerClassName) (this is how Google supports running the same tests on Local JVM and Devices).

**Team decision:** Introduce new `junit.vintage.discovery.issue.reporting.enabled=false` configuration parameter and defer introducing a more general mechanism for changing the severity of discovery issues or their criticality later, if necessary.
